There was an Englishman staying at the hotel in Brandon, his wife area we go and take care of the children. They live upstairs.

We were much amused, for being a single board floor, acts no supports if swayed well every step we took. We happened to spill the water the woman underneath came up and told us it was coming through the floor!

When I was at Barna in Ontario, we did go to school there, so we learned to read, and my Aunt Alethia gave us a portion of scripture to read every day, so that helped us keep up our reading. We children stayed at home until we could work or help our elderly mother and (who came with us) also say elderly brother back to work on the railway at Brandon.

We all went back there to live. My Aunt Eliza (Uncle Stewart's wife) came & helped with us & take care of any another till she died.

Aunt Eliza took the 2 eldest girls, Harle & Minnie, & the 2 youngest stayed with Grand Brother Fleming on a farm outside Brandon on a rented farm.
There was an Englishman staying at the hotel in Brandon, his wife and two children. They were upstairs.

We were much amused, for seeing a single broad floor, with no supports, I swayed with every step we took. We happened to fall over the woman underneath, cause of and did not fall through the floor!

When I was at Barrie in Ontario, we also go to school there, so we learned to read, and my Aunt Atkinson gave us a portion of scripture to read every day, so that helped us keep up our reading. We children stayed there until the winter came (with us) also my eldest brother went back to work on the railway at Brandon.

We all went back there to live. My Aunt Eliza (Uncle Stewart's wife) came & stayed with us late last year. My mother till she died.

Aunt Eliza took the 2 eldest girls, Nellie & Ronnie, & the 2 youngest, Albert & Grand Brother. Nellie on a farm outside Brandon on a rented farm.
There were no schools even in Brandon at that time so my oldest sister went to work on a farm. I stayed with Uncle Tom Fleming at the place now called Summerberry. They were just Harvey relatives but there were not enough people & get the school closed so my father went to Minnedosa where I was then to get his, and other people took children to their homes to go to make the required number of pupils.

I was then 12, but did not have readily & school so my father found me a job with a Mr. Paul as a seaman's horse where I stayed 4 years. I got married at Motley at 18 & John Way we worked for an Englishman, a big man, Mr. Clark.

Then we worked at the hotel in Selkirk. I got $10 a month there. I remember once when we were travelling we came across a farm they had broken true head but as we came near it & the fence had become tangled on the way from the east. My father told them how & nearly that by stopping the hay & flour in cold water & then hanging it up & dry & they would keep indefinitely.

After we worked at the Supernatural Farm at Selkirk Place when George Breckley was Superintendent.
There were no schools even in Brandon at that time so my oldest sister went to work on a farm. I stayed with Uncle Tom Fleming at the place now called Strawberry. They were just starting school but there were not enough pupils to get the school grant, so my father went to Minnedosa, where I was then to get me, and other people took children to their homes to go to make the required number of pupils.

I was then 12, but did not have ready to school so my father found me a job with a Mr. Paul as a section hand, where I stayed 4 years. I got married at Moleeley at 18 to John Wray. We worked for an Englishman, a big man named Clark.

Then we worked at the hotel in Brandon. He got $10 a month there. I remember once when we were travelling we came across a farm they had broken loose hand, but we could earn it as the floor had become tangled on the way from the east. My father told them how to remedy that by deploying the legs of floor in cold water, then hanging it up by air, and it would keep indefinitely.

After we came to the Experimental Farm at Jackson Road when Carolyn Brookley was superintendent.
We once had a Reunion of the Fleming family at Uncle Louis' farm at Summerberry. It lasted more than a week for them all. Course, for about 300 attended the gathering.

This took place in 1932 or '33.

At one time we were in Regina, my husband working in the Saskatchewan Building and I kept a boarding house. Suddenly my eldest son had typhoid fever and died, and my girls both had scarlet fever. 2 of them had to go to hospital in a denveral, not an ambulance, for fear of infection.

One day 2 of my girls were sitting on the verandah conversing, I was about 5 p.m. All at once there was a terrific sound. They say electricity started & go but the sound was so strong I went inside & shut the door. A very loud sound came from outside. I opened the door & found the lights before. For some reason the sewer had broken up.

So we just hung on to the branches &
We once had a reunion of the Heming family at Uncle Louis' farm at Summerberry. It lasted more than a week for them all to come. For about 3 or 4 weeks, the gathering took place in 1932 or 33.

At one time we were in Regan, my husband working in the Supplement Building and I kept a boarding house. Unfortunately, my eldest son had typhoid fever and died, and my girls both had typhoid fever and died, and my girls both had typhoid fever. Two of them had to go to hospital in a denver car, not an ambulance, for fear of infection.

One day, if any girls were feeling on the germs, convalescing, it was about 5 p.m., all at once there was a terrific wind. They say it cleared up, but the wind was so strong I went there that the door a window started me for ad "go on the basement" and saw the cellar flooded. It had rained the night before, for some reason the sewer had broken up, so we just hung on to the branches as
The house was shaking, we didn't know what was going to happen. The cyclone tipped the house all over side, back of the roof was blown off, a ventilated floor & pieces. Afterwards I saw pieces of my kitchen furniture scattered outside, & I looked tallied all around.

I only found a few & they had no feathers or they looked as if they had been plucked! Two of my young men brothers cause & see what had happened to us, & took us to an hotel. We had to go the next road, as the streets were otherwise with fallen telephone poles, there was a big fire eventually we had a tent given us by the P.M.C.P which we put up in the back yard of our house till the house was remodelled. We stayed in it 2 months.

The 1st July was a Monday that year so people used the Sunday & do all the ceremonies since then the 1st has never been celebrated in Regina, as they worked upon the capitol at a judgment for breaking the Sabbath.
The house was shaking, so we didn't know what was going to happen. The cyclone tipped the house all over side, part of the roof was blown off, a veranda, floor & pieces. Afterwards I saw pieces of my bedroom furniture scattered outside, & I heard told all around. When I went back for my chickens they looked as if they had been frightened or they had been poisoned! Two of my young ones besides came & see what had happened & us & took us in hotel. We had to go the next morning, and the streets were therefore left fallen telephone poles, & there was a big fire. We were afraid of something a love wire eventually we had a tent given us by the R.M.C.P which we put up in the street yard of our house till the house was reconditioned. We stayed at it 2 months.

The 1st July was a Friday that year so people used the Sunday & do all the alterations since then the 1st has never been celebrated in Perguia, as they worked upon the cyclone as a punishment for breaking the Sabbath.
The Manager,

Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
My father had worked in different places, I had heard about the West. They knew I had a hard winter out by our old homestead.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
Travelled with my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Car or covered wagon, enduring all our experiences.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
We stopped overnight at a farm house where a bachelor shared the spread in the case of his horse. We went and slept in the loft. We waited our turn on the floor downstairs. A boy was out fording the river and we started again.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
I stayed at my Uncle Joe's farm where I called Quackenberry. They were kind enough to let me stay there until I could find work.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
I took up land near the town of Quackenberry.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
After I arrived in Saskatchewan, I worked for a rancher and then for a farmer.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?
I only got $10 a month and would be working here working at the hotel.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My father had worked in a sawmill for years and had heard about the work in Western Canada.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled with my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We used covered wagons, containing all our possessions.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We stopped overnight at a farm house where a bachelor lived. The house was the size of two houses. We went and looked in the loft; we found two beds on the floor covered with a blanket. We found food from the wagon and bought more provisions when we started again.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I stayed at my uncle's place, then I went to the places and called them.

They were very friendly to me there, but as time went by, I became lonely and decided to go back to my parents' place.

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

I only got $10 a month and worked at buying them working at the hotel.
